DOC.HEAD: France Offers To Back Intervention by Soviets or Volunteers
Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Dumas saying France to coordinate with Soviets on aid, French army to send help; pickup graf 6 pvs ``If other ...''
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister Sunday offered to help put together a ``brigade of volunteers'' to help Romanians fight forces loyal to ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. If the Soviet Union thought it necessary to intervene in Romania on the side of the anti-Ceausescu forces, France ``not only would not object to it, but would support this action,'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas told Soviet officials. There was no indication, however, of imminent military intervention by Soviet or other forces. Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said Saturday that sending the Red Army to Romania would be ``impermissible'' and a repetition of past mistakes. In a later interview Sunday on French TV, Dumas said the Soviets ``have just now let us know today that they are in agreement to begin with us to coordinate all our aid.'' He did not elaborate, but it was clear he meant humanitarian, rather than military aid. The French army said it will provide 10 trucks and 30 soldiers to help deliver medical aid to Romania. In a short statement Sunday, the Foreign Ministry said France recognizes the National Salvation Committee as the legal authority in Romania. So far, France has only been asked for humanitarian aid, but it stands ready to respond if asked to go beyond humanitarian measures, Dumas said on French radio. ``If other requests are made _ I don't know how the events will unfold _ if another demand is made, we will appraise it. I can tell you we are ready to respond to any new situation,'' he said. The foreign minister then added, ``Myself, I could very well see the constitution of a brigade of volunteers. France could help in it.'' Interviewed by Agence France-Presse, Dumas recalled the volunteers who participated in the Spanish Civil War and in the liberation of France from Nazi occupation in 1944. ``Many people talk, but don't take enough action,'' he said. In an interview on French TV, however, Dumas said Western participation in military intervention in Romania ``would pose problems, because the region is a zone of the Warsaw Pact.'' Romanian-born playwright Eugene Ionesco, who lives in France, urged the West ``to provide military aid in arms and ammunition to the regular Romanian army so it can defend the people against the agents of the security police.'' France has sent two planeloads of medical supplies and emergency medical teams to Romania in a mission led by Bernard Kouchner, minister for humanitarian action in the Socialist government.
